questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with widespread edema, skin ulcers, and high blood pressure. Urine analysis reveals subnephrotic proteinuria (<2g/day) and microscopic hematuria. Serum complement levels are reduced, and she tests positive for anti-hepatitis C antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Essential Mixed Cryoglobulinemia

 

Explanation: 

 

Essential mixed cryoglobulinemia is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The patient presents with the classic triad of purpura (skin ulcers), arthralgia, and weakness. This condition is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection, which the patient tests positive for. The presence of hypocomplementemia (reduced serum complement levels) along with mild proteinuria and hematuria further supports this diagnosis. Mixed cryoglobulinemia typically involves a vasculitic process that can present with skin lesions and kidney manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis: While post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can present with hypocomplementemia and hematuria, it typically occurs after streptococcal infections, not hepatitis C. It generally affects children and young adults, and the patient's age (60) makes this less likely. Additionally, it doesn't typically cause the widespread edema and skin ulcers described.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN): MPGN can be associated with hepatitis C and low complement levels. However, MPGN typically presents with more significant proteinuria (often nephrotic range) than described in this case. While MPGN can be secondary to cryoglobulinemia, the clinical presentation more directly points to cryoglobulinemia as the primary diagnosis.

 

Option D. Focal Segmental Glomerular Sclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is not typically associated with hepatitis C infection or hypocomplementemia. It usually presents with significant proteinuria (often nephrotic range) without the systemic manifestations seen in this patient (skin ulcers, vasculitis).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hepatitis C virus infection is strongly associated with mixed cryoglobulinemia, which can manifest with skin lesions, arthralgia, weakness, hypocomplementemia, and kidney involvement with subnephrotic proteinuria and microscopic hematuria.

questions.text: In a community of 100000 population, 105 children were born in a year, out of which 5 were still births and 2 died within 6 months after birth and another 2 died within next 6 months. The IMR (Infant Mortality Rate) is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 40

 

Explanation:

 

The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated by dividing the total number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) by the total number of live births, and multiplying the result by 1,000.

 

In this case, the given information is:

 

  • Total births in a year = 105
  • Stillbirths = 5
  • Infant deaths within the first 6 months = 2
  • Infant deaths within the next 6 months = 2

 

To calculate the IMR:

 

1. Calculate the number of live births:

Total live births = Total births - Stillbirths

Total live births = 105 - 5 = 100

 

2. Calculate the total number of infant deaths:

Total infant deaths = Infant deaths within the first 6 months + Infant deaths within the next 6 months

Total infant deaths = 2 + 2 = 4

 

3. Calculate the IMR using the formula:

IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) × 1,000

IMR = (4 / 100) × 1,000

IMR = 40

Therefore, the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for this community is 40 per 1,000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is a crucial indicator that represents the number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) per 1,000 live births in a given population or community.

questions.text: A patient complains that he often gets troubled at night during sleep by tingling and numbness that involves his lateral three digits. He further explains that symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Correct regarding the condition is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CTS: Durkan test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is the entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum
  • Clinical features:
    • 8 times more common in females
    • Usual age group is 50 years
    • Burning pain, paresthesia, tingling and numbness in median nerve distribution



       
    • Pain increased by activities, more troublesome at night; relieved by handing the arm over the side of bed or by shaking the arm
    • Clumsiness and weakness in tasks requiring fine manipulation
       
  • Special tests:
    • Sensory symptoms can be reproduced by percussion over the median nerve – Tinel’s sign
    • Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by holding the wrist in full flexion for a minute – Phalen’s test/Reverse Phalen’s test

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • The most specific test for carpal tunnel syndrome is Durkans test – Direct compression over the median nerve – best clinical test – done by holding wrist in slight flexion and directly compressing the nerve by applying pressure to proximal wrist crease for 30 seconds – development of pain, paresthesia or numbness indicates a positive test.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CTS: Froment sign. Froment’s sign is seen in cases of ulnar nerve palsy where the adductor pollicis is paralysed. The patient is made to hold a book between the thumb and the palm. In case of ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will hold the book using the flexor pollicis longus muscle, which will produce flexion at the IP joint.

 

 

This sign is specific of ulnar nerve palsy and will be negative in carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C. Guyon canal syndrome: Froment sign. Guyon Canal syndrome, also known as Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome/ulnar tunnel syndrome/handlebar palsy, is a relatively rare peripheral ulnar neuropathy. It is defined as a compression of the distal ulnar nerve at the level of the wrist as it enters the hand through a space called ulnar tunnel or Guyon canal. The clinical presentation can be purely sensory, purely motor or both depending on the location of the nerve compression. Froment’s sign will be positive in this case.

 

Option D. Guyon canal syndrome: Durkan test. Durkan test is the most specific and sensitive for carpal tunnel syndrome only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is primarily found in tendons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Collagen

 

Explanation: 

 

Tendons are dense, fibrous connective tissues that connect muscle to bone and transmit force during movement. Collagen, specifically fibrillar type I collagen, is the predominant component of tendons, making up approximately 60-85% of the dry weight of the tendon. These collagen fibers are arranged in parallel bundles that provide the high tensile strength necessary for tendons to withstand and transmit the mechanical forces generated during muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrin - Fibrin is not a normal component of tendons. It is a fibrous protein formed from fibrinogen during blood clotting and is involved in wound healing rather than tendon structure.

 

Option C. Fibrillin - While fibrillin is an important extracellular matrix glycoprotein associated with elastin in elastic fibers, it is primarily found in tissues requiring elasticity such as blood vessels, skin, and ligaments. It is not a major component of tendons, which require tensile strength rather than elasticity.

 

Option D. Proteoglycans - Although proteoglycans are present in tendons, they make up a much smaller proportion compared to collagen. They contribute to the viscoelastic properties of tendons and help maintain tissue hydration, but they are not the primary structural component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tendons are composed primarily of type I collagen arranged in parallel bundles, providing the high tensile strength required for their function of transmitting force from muscle to bone.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is strictly contraindicated during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate

 

Methotrexate is strictly contraindicated during pregnancy as it's classified as an FDA Category X drug. It poses proven fetal risks that clearly outweigh any possible therapeutic benefit. Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that causes craniofacial, axial skeletal, and gastrointestinal malformations in the developing fetus. Its teratogenic effects are severe enough to warrant complete avoidance during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclosporine: While cyclosporine is a cytotoxic drug that might cause immune suppression in breastfed infants, it is not strictly contraindicated during pregnancy. Cytotoxic drugs may cause teratogenic effects in the first trimester, but cyclosporine is not classified in Category X.

 

Option C. Chloroquine: Chloroquine shows no evidence of fetal toxicity when used in therapeutic doses for malaria. The benefits of chloroquine treatment typically outweigh the risks during pregnancy, making it acceptable for use when indicated.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: While caution is advised with most medications during pregnancy, pyrazinamide is not identified as strictly contraindicated in pregnancy in the way methotrexate is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate is a Category X medication with proven severe teratogenic effects, making it absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy regardless of potential therapeutic benefits

choices.text: Only CD4 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Only CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 protected against graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

questions.text: For the given Kaplan-Meier curve on the role of T-cells in the allograft rejection process, true statement is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

 

The Kaplan-Meier curve presented in this question shows the survival rates of grafts in mice after they were treated with monoclonal antibodies designed to deplete specific T-cells (CD4 and CD8). The survival curves illustrate how the presence or absence of these T-cells affects graft rejection.

 

  • Anti-CD8 Group (Pink Line): The curve for mice treated with anti-CD8 antibodies (which deplete CD8 T-cells) shows a survival rate very similar to the control group. This indicates that the removal of CD8 T-cells alone does not significantly affect graft survival.
  • Anti-CD4 Group (Blue Line): The curve for the anti-CD4 group shows an extended graft survival compared to the control and anti-CD8 groups. This indicates that CD4 T-cells play a more significant role in graft rejection than CD8 T-cells alone. Removal of CD4 prolongs survival from 15 to 30 days.
  • Anti-CD4 + Anti-CD8 Group (Green Line): The green curve represents mice treated with both anti-CD4 and anti-CD8 antibodies. This group shows the longest survival of grafts, extending up to 60 days. The combination of depleting both CD4 and CD8 T-cells significantly delays graft rejection, demonstrating that both types of T-cells are involved in the rejection process.

 

The conclusion drawn from this curve is that both CD4 and CD8 T-cells contribute to graft rejection, and their combined effect is more pronounced than the effect of either cell type alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both CD4 and CD8 T-cells are crucial contributors to the allograft rejection process, and their combined depletion significantly prolongs graft survival.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?(NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flexion

 

  • The primary function of the muscle marked is to facilitate flexion of the finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint. Flexion involves bending the finger, reducing the angle between the metacarpal bone (in the palm) and the proximal phalanx (the first bone of the finger). This muscle contributes to the closing of the fingers into a grip.
  • Muscles Involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus,  Flexor Digitorum Superficialis, Flexor Pollicis Longus , Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and Flexor Carpi Radialis: These muscles flex the wrist.

 

 

 

  • Lumbricals are the muscles that cause flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus in the palm give rise to the 4 lumbrical (worm-like) muscles.
  • Medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively;Supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively; Supplied by digital branches of the median nerve
  • The lumbrical muscles have tendons that pass over the outer side of each finger and attach to the extensor hood. They are located in front of the deep transverse metacarpal ligaments.

 

The muscle marked in the image, at the metacarpophalangeal joint, is likely involved in finger movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extension (Incorrect): Extension of the finger is the opposite movement of flexion. It involves straightening the finger, increasing the angle between the metacarpal bone and the proximal phalanx. The muscle in question is not primarily responsible for extension. Muscles Involved are Extensor Digitorum, Extensor Pollicis Longus , Extensor Carpi Ulnaris and Extensor Carpi Radialis.

 

Option C. Adduction (Incorrect): Adduction of the finger would involve moving the finger toward the midline or toward adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not oriented to perform adduction. Adduction of the fingers typically involves the intrinsic muscles of the hand, which are located within the hand itself

 

Option D. Abduction (Incorrect): Abduction of the finger would involve moving the finger away from the midline or away from adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not positioned to perform abduction. The specific muscles responsible for abduction are part of the dorsal interossei and palmar interossei muscle group

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbricals are essential for the flexion of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, contributing significantly to the dexterity and functional complexity of the hand, particularly in actions that require a combination of flexing and extending different joints of the fingers, such as typing or playing certain musical instruments.

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy. This condition is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the tissues around the eyes, leading to inflammation and swelling. This results in the characteristic bulging of the eyes, known as proptosis or exophthalmos.

 

Thyroid eye disease is particularly common in middle-aged individuals and can cause both unilateral (one eye) and bilateral (both eyes) proptosis. The pathophysiology involves the expansion of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, leading to the protrusion of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tissue tumour in orbit: While soft tissue tumors in the orbit can cause proptosis, they are not the most common cause in middle-aged individuals. These tumors can be benign or malignant and require imaging studies for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Optic nerve meningioma: This type of tumor is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and can lead to proptosis. However, it is less common compared to thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Although cavernous hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in adults, it is not the most common cause of proptosis. These benign vascular tumors can cause proptosis if they become large enough to displace the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT associated with granulomatous pathology? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Polyarteritis nodosa (classic PAN)

 

Explanation:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by a necrotizing inflammation of small and medium-sized muscular arteries, but it does not typically demonstrate granulomatous features. PAN is a panarteritis that involves neutrophil infiltration of all layers of the vessel wall with fibrinoid necrosis, leading to compromise of the vascular lumen, thrombosis, and tissue infarction. However, granuloma formation - a hallmark of many other vasculitides - is notably absent in classic PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's):  it is characterized by necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving small arteries and veins. The histopathologic hallmarks include granuloma formation that may be intravascular or extravascular, which is crucial to its diagnosis.

 

Option B. Arteritis of Takayasu:  it demonstrates granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall. The pathological features include granulomatous panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasional giant cells.

 

Option D. Arteritis of the giant cell type:  it is defined by granulomatous vasculitis with giant cell formation. This is a panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates within the vessel wall and frequent giant cell formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classic polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing, non-granulomatous vasculitis of medium-sized arteries, distinguishing it from other major vasculitides like GPA, Takayasu arteritis, and Giant Cell Arteritis, which all demonstrate granulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

 

Explanation:

 

Chickenpox in Pregnancy:

 

  • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes:
    • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
    • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.

 

Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.

 

Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.

 

Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Contralateral loss of pain sensation
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions
Contralateral motor functions

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Contralateral loss of pain sensation

 

Brown Sequard syndrome is produced due to lateral hemi-section of spinal cord.

 

Clinical features include:

 

  1. Ipsilateral weakness +
  2. Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense +
  3. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature sense one or two levels below lesion +
  4. Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of tendon reflex

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contralateral loss of joint sense and position: Incorrect, as joint sense and position loss occur ipsilaterally due to dorsal column damage.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions: Incorrect, sensory loss is not complete and is dissociated; pain and temperature sensations are lost contralaterally while proprioception and vibration are lost ipsilaterally.

 

Option D. Contralateral motor functions: Incorrect, motor function loss (weakness or paralysis) occurs ipsilaterally below the level of the lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Brown-Sequard syndrome, the characteristic neurological pattern includes ipsilateral motor weakness and proprioceptive loss, alongside contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, due to a lateral hemisection of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P2L2 woman presents with cervical elongation. Her family is complete. What is the preferred surgery advised? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fothergill


The Fothergill procedure, also known as the Manchester repair, is the preferred surgical treatment for women with cervical elongation who have completed their families and do not wish to have more children. This procedure involves cervical amputation and reinforcement of the pelvic ligaments, providing adequate support without removing the uterus. It is suitable for younger women who are not candidates for a hysterectomy but have significant cervical elongation contributing to prolapse symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. McCall Culdoplasty: This procedure is typically performed to correct vaginal vault prolapse during or after hysterectomy and is not specifically indicated for cervical elongation.

 

Option C. Le fort: This procedure involves partial closure of the vagina and is generally recommended for elderly, non-sexually active women who are not candidates for more invasive surgeries.

 

Option D. Shirodkar sling: This procedure is used for pelvic organ prolapse in young, nulliparous women or women who wish to preserve fertility by anchoring the uterus, usually to the sacral promontory. It is not indicated for women with completed families and cervical elongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolapse management by age group:

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

 

The presence of empty appearing nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

 

  • Histological Appearance: Papillary carcinoma has a papillary growth pattern with branching papillae composed of fibrovascular stalks and cuboidal epithelial cells.
  • Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei: Papillary carcinoma cells have distinct Orphan Annie eye nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and an optically clear or empty appearance.
  • Psammoma Bodies: Papillary carcinoma often contains psammoma bodies, which are concentrically calcified structures found within the papillae.
  • Lymphatic Invasion: Papillary carcinoma commonly exhibits lymphatic invasion; involvement of blood vessels is uncommon.
  • Genetic Alterations: Papillary carcinoma is associated with specific genetic changes, including gene rearrangements like RET/PTC and NTRK1, as well as BRAF gene mutations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular carcinoma: This is incorrect. Follicular carcinoma typically presents with a different histological pattern, characterized by small follicles. It does not exhibit Orphan Annie eye nuclei, which are specific to papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Toxic nodular goitre: This is incorrect. Toxic nodular goitre, or multinodular goitre, is a benign condition and does not present with Orphan Annie eye nuclei or the other specific histological features of papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: This is incorrect. Medullary carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is characterized by amyloid deposits and the presence of calcitonin, rather than the histological features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathological examination is a key diagnostic feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

choices.text: Na- Ca transporter

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SGLT1

 

Explanation

 

ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT2: Incorrect. SGLT2 is another sodium-glucose linked transporter but is primarily found in the kidneys where it reabsorbs glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream. It is not involved in intestinal glucose absorption and thus not relevant to ORS function.

 

Option C. GLUT4: Incorrect. GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found mainly in adipose tissues and muscle cells. It is not involved in the intestinal absorption of glucose and plays no role in ORS therapy.

 

Option D. Na-Ca transporter: Incorrect. The sodium-calcium exchanger (often referred to as NCX) is primarily involved in the transport of calcium and sodium ions across the cell membrane in many tissues, including cardiac muscle. It does not participate in glucose absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A biopsy was performed on a patient with a recurrent chalazion involving the upper eyelid. What is the most likely diagnosis on histopathology? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sebaceous Cell Carcinoma

 

Sebaceous cell carcinoma can often masquerade as a recurrent chalazion, making it a diagnostic challenge. It arises from the meibomian glands and frequently involves the upper eyelid. This malignancy typically presents initially as a nodule that may be mistaken for a chalazion, more frequently on the upper eyelid. Recurrent chalazion that doesn't respond to conventional treatment should raise suspicion for this malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: While this is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelids (90% of eyelid malignancies), it typically presents as a noduloulcerative lesion with pearly rolled margins (rodent ulcer). It most commonly affects the lower eyelid (50%) followed by medial canthus, and doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: This presents as a scaly, erythematous plaque with elevated and indurated margins or occasionally as nodular/polypoidal growth. It commonly arises from the lid margin, not from the meibomian glands, and doesn't typically resemble a chalazion.

 

Option D. Malignant Melanoma: This rare eyelid tumor (less than 1% of eyelid lesions) presents as a pigmented, well-defined lesion that later becomes elevated, or as a nodular growth. It doesn't typically mimic a chalazion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recurrent chalazia, especially in older patients, should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, warranting histopathological examination to avoid misdiagnosis of this potentially lethal malignancy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: Which of the following causes mitochondrial damage by inhibiting ATP synthase?(NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oligomycin

 

Explanation:

 

Oligomycin is a specific inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It acts by ligating the F₀ gate and closing it, thereby preventing the flow of protons through this channel. By blocking the F₀ portion of ATP synthase, oligomycin prevents the conversion of ADP to ATP, leading to mitochondrial damage due to energy depletion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bromate: This is incorrect because bromate is not a mitochondrial inhibitor. It is not described as having effects on ATP synthase or any component of the electron transport chain.

 

Option B. Cyanide: This is incorrect because while cyanide is a mitochondrial toxin, it specifically inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) of the electron transport chain, not ATP synthase. Cyanide prevents oxygen from being the final electron acceptor.

 

Option C. Desipramine: This is incorrect because desipramine is not a mitochondrial toxin. It is not described as having effects on ATP synthase or other components of the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically inhibits ATP synthase (Complex V) by blocking the F₀ proton channel, preventing proton flow and ATP synthesis, which distinguishes it from other mitochondrial toxins that affect different aspects of the electron transport chain.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothelial injury

 

Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

 

Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system.

 


 

Three primary abnormalities, known as the Virchow triad, are known to cause thrombosis.

 

They include:

 

  • Endothelial injury - most important factor
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet activation: While platelet activation is a crucial step in the formation of a thrombus, it is typically initiated by endothelial injury, making endothelial injury the primary initiating event.

 

Option C. Coagulation cascade: The coagulation cascade is activated following endothelial injury and platelet activation, but it is not the initiating event of thrombosis.

 

Option D. Vasoconstriction of vessels: Vasoconstriction occurs as a response to endothelial injury and helps limit blood flow to the site of injury, but it is not the initiating factor in thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombosis is primarily initiated by endothelial injury, which is a key component of the Virchow triad and leads to the subsequent activation of platelets and the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

 

The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

 

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used.

 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black.

 

Yellow-green colonies are seen in case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and Option B. Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

 

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

 

 

Option C. Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor.

 

Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

 

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of respiratory infections in immunocompromised patients, the presence of dichotomous branching at acute angles in histopathological examination should prompt consideration of Aspergillus infection, necessitating prompt antifungal therapy to manage the potential for invasive disease.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Obstructive jaundice

 

The laboratory findings indicate elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels while other liver enzymes are normal. This pattern is most consistent with obstructive jaundice.

 

In this condition, there is an obstruction in the bile ducts that prevents bile from being excreted into the intestine, leading to an accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood. Alkaline phosphatase is typically elevated in conditions that involve cholestasis (impaired bile flow), which is characteristic of obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice: This type of jaundice is caused by the excessive breakdown of red blood cells, leading to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin. Alkaline phosphatase levels remain normal in hemolytic jaundice.

 

Option C. Hepatic jaundice: Hepatic jaundice occurs due to liver cell damage, which impairs the liver's ability to process and excrete bilirubin. This condition typically shows elevated transaminases (ALT, AST), not just alkaline phosphatase.

 

Option D. Prehepatic jaundice: This term is often used interchangeably with hemolytic jaundice, where the problem lies before the bilirubin reaches the liver. Elevated unconjugated bilirubin and normal alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in prehepatic jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where laboratory investigations reveal elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase with normal other liver enzymes, obstructive jaundice should be considered as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is diagnosed with osteosarcoma and is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy as part of his treatment. Methotrexate is included in his chemotherapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of his osteosarcoma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR.

 

Methotrexate has different mechanisms for anticancer activity and for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

 

Mechanism in Osteosarcoma (As anticancer drug): Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate interferes with the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, an essential cofactor for DNA synthesis. This leads to a decrease in DNA and RNA synthesis, thereby arresting the cell cycle and inhibiting the growth of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells in osteosarcoma.

 

Mechanism in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): Methotrexate is used at much lower doses in Rheumatoid Arthritis. In this condition, the major mechanism involves the inhibition of an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, part of the purine synthesis pathway. When AICAR transformylase is inhibited, levels of AICAR (5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide ribonucleotide) accumulate in the cell. This leads to an inhibition of another enzyme called adenosine deaminase, which is responsible for the degradation of adenosine. As a result, adenosine levels increase within the cell and in the extracellular environment. Adenosine is known to have anti-inflammatory properties. When adenosine interacts with its receptors, it can lead to various effects such as inhibition of inflammatory cell function, vasodilation, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine release. These actions contribute to the anti-inflammatory effects observed when methotrexate is used for treating RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analog of UMP: Methotrexate is not an analog of UMP (uridine monophosphate). It does not exert its effects through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Blocks purine synthesis: Methotrexate does not specifically block purine synthesis, although the inhibition of DHFR indirectly affects purine and pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Blocks pyrimidine synthesis: Similar to Option C, methotrexate does not specifically block pyrimidine synthesis but indirectly affects it through DHFR inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate's primary mechanism of action in treating osteosarcoma is as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: The following diagram depicts the fluctuation in population over the years spanning from 1983 to 1989 within a specific location. Which type of statistical diagram is being employed in this instance? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Component bar graph

 

  • The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.
  • A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.
  • In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Histogram is used for continuous quantitative data presentation.

 

 

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are

 

separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

 

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

 

Option B. Line Diagram: Is a better chart Used in depiction of TREND. There is no closed loop and no histogram in the background.

 

 

Option D. Multiple Bar Graphs: Multiple bar graphs show two or more sets of data simultaneously with separate bars for each category side by side. This is different from a component bar graph, where each bar is divided into segments representing different components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A component bar graph is used to represent data where the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components, effectively illustrating the proportion of each category within the total value.

questions.text: A patient presents with an BT leprosy lesion on the face as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Facial Nerve

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests a case of leprosy, with the facial nerve being the most commonly affected cranial nerve.

 

  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which impacts the mucous membranes, cutaneous tissues, and peripheral nerves leading to sensory and motor deficits.

 

Most commonly affected nerves:

 

  • Peripheral nerves: Ulnar > Posterior tibial nerve, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.
  • Cranial nerves: Facial nerve > Trigeminal nerve.
  • Notably, facial skin lesions are associated with a 10-fold increase in the risk of facial nerve involvement in leprosy cases.
  • Facial nerve involvement can lead to facial muscle weakness, paralysis, and loss of facial expressions, which are characteristic features of this condition.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve:

 

  • The trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve) primarily innervates the face and is responsible for sensations such as touch and pain.
  • While it can be affected in leprosy, it is not the most commonly involved nerve in BT leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve:

 

  • The abducens nerve (sixth cranial nerve) controls the movement of the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.
  • In leprosy, it is less commonly involved compared to the facial nerve, especially in BT leprosy.

 

Option D. Optic nerve:

 

The optic nerve (second cranial nerve) is responsible for vision and is not commonly affected in leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with leprosy lesions on the face, the most commonly involved nerve is the facial nerve (option A).

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 28, Page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below as A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fascia transversalis

 

Marked structure is the deep inguinal ring, formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

 

An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal Oblique:  The internal oblique muscle is one of the three major muscles of the lateral abdominal wall. It lies just deep to the external oblique and superficial to the transversus abdominis.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the lumbar fascia, anterior two-thirds of the iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It inserts into the lower ribs, linea alba, and the pubic bone.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option B. External Oblique: The external oblique is the most superficial of the three flat muscles of the lateral abdominal wall.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the outer surfaces of the 5th to 12th ribs and inserts into the linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of the iliac crest.
  • Innervation: Like the internal oblique, it's innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option C. Parietal Peritoneum: The parietal peritoneum is the outer layer of the peritoneum that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall.

 

  • Composition: It consists of a single layer of squamous epithelial cells (mesothelium) and its underlying connective tissue.
  • Innervation: The parietal peritoneum overlying the anterior abdominal wall is primarily innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fascia Transversalis: The fascia transversalis is a thin aponeurotic membrane which lies between the inner surface of the transversus abdominis muscle and the parietal peritoneum. It covers the entire inner surface of the abdominal wall and is continuous with the iliac and pelvic fasciae.

 

Hernias that penetrate the fascia transversalis in the groin region are called direct inguinal hernias.
